His extensive writings, the most famous being A Short Account of the D

heading: Deaths
txt: Jacobus Gallus, Slovenian composer (b. 1550)

entities.title: Jacobus Gallus
entities.description: Jacobus Gallus was a late-Renaissance composer of presumed Slovene ethnicity. Born in Carniola, which at the time was one of the Habsburg lands in the Holy Roman Empire, he lived and worked in Moravia and Bohemia during the last decade of his life.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joachim Frederick, Elector of Brandenburg (b. 1546)

entities.title: Joachim Frederick, Elector of Brandenburg
entities.description: Joachim Frederick, of the House of Hohenzollern, was Prince-elector of the Margraviate of Brandenburg from 1598 until his death.

heading: Deaths
txt: Caravaggio, Italian painter (b. 1571)

entities.title: Caravaggio
entities.description: Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio was an Italian painter active in Rome for most of his artistic life. During the final four years of his life he moved between Naples, Malta, and Sicily until his death. His paintings combine a realistic observation of the human state, both physical and emotional, with a dramatic use of lighting, which had a formative influence on Baroque painting.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bernard of Saxe-Weimar, German general (b. 1604)

entities.title: Bernard of Saxe-Weimar
entities.description: Bernard of Saxe-Weimar was a German prince and general in the Thirty Years' War.

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Levinz, English Royalist, hanged in London by Parliamentary forces as a spy (b. 1615)

entities.title: Robert Levinz
entities.description: Robert Levinz, Levens or Levinge, Royalist, was a son of William Levinz of Senkworth, near Abingdon, who carried on the business of a brewer at Oxford. His grandfather, William Levinz, was an alderman of Oxford, and five times mayor at the close of the sixteenth century; he was buried in All Saints Church, where there is a fine recumbent effigy to his memory. Robert was uncle of Sir Creswell Lev

heading: Deaths
txt: Johannes Camphuys, Dutch politician, Governor-General of the Dutch East Indies (b. 1634)

entities.title: Johannes Camphuys
entities.description: Johannes Camphuys was the Governor-General of the Dutch East Indies from 1684 to 1691. Camphuys was born in Haarlem, in the Republic of the United Netherlands.

entities.title: Governor-General of the Dutch East Indies
entities.description: The Governor-General of the Dutch East Indies represented Dutch rule in the Dutch East Indies between 1610 and Dutch recognition of the independence of Indonesia in 1949.

heading: Deaths
txt: Johann Heinrich Heidegger, Swiss theologian and author (b. 1633)

entities.title: Johann Heinrich Heidegger
entities.description: Johann Heinrich Heidegger, Swiss theologian, was born at Bäretswil, in the Canton of Zürich.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean-Antoine Watteau, French painter (b. 1684)

entities.title: Jean-Antoine Watteau
entities.description: Jean-Antoine Watteau was a French painter and draughtsman whose brief career spurred the revival of interest in colour and movement, as seen in the tradition of Correggio and Rubens. He revitalized the waning Baroque style, shifting it to the less severe, more naturalistic, less formally classical, Rococo. Watteau is credited with inventing the genre of fêtes galantes, scenes of bucolic and idylli

heading: Deaths
txt: François de Neufville, duc de Villeroy, French general (b. 1644)

entities.title: François de Neufville, duc de Villeroy
entities.description: François de Neufville, (2nd) Duke of Villeroy was a French soldier.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pieter Langendijk, Dutch poet and playwright (b. 1683)

entities.title: Pieter Langendijk
entities.description: Pieter Langendijk was a damask weaver, city artist, dramatist, and poet.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Paul Jones, Scottish-American admiral and diplomat (b. 1747)

entities.title: John Paul Jones
entities.description: John Paul Jones was the United States' first well-known naval commander in the American Revolutionary War. He made many friends among U.S political elites, as well as enemies, and his actions in British waters during the Revolution earned him an international reputation which persists to this day. As such, he is sometimes referred to as the "Father of the American Navy".

heading: Deaths
txt: Jane Austen, English novelist  (b. 1775)

entities.title: Jane Austen
entities.description: Jane Austen was an English novelist known primarily for her six major novels, which interpret, critique and comment upon the British landed gentry at the end of the 18th century. Austen's plots often explore the dependence of women on marriage in the pursuit of favourable social standing and economic security. Her works critique the novels of sensibility of the second half of the 18th century and

heading: Deaths
txt: Vincenzo Borg, Maltese merchant and rebel leader (b. 1777)

entities.title: Vincenzo Borg
entities.description: Vincenzo Maria Borg, also known by his nickname Brared, was a Maltese merchant who was one of the main insurgent leaders during the French blockade of 1798–1800. He was a lieutenant from 1801 until he was deposed in January 1804.

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Gould Shaw, American colonel (b. 1837)

entities.title: Robert Gould Shaw
entities.description: Robert Gould Shaw was an American officer in the Union Army during the American Civil War. Born into a prominent Boston abolitionist family, he accepted command of the first all-black regiment in the Northeast. Supporting the promised equal treatment for his troops, he encouraged the men to refuse their pay until it was equal to that of white troops' wage.

heading: Deaths
txt: Benito Juárez, Mexican lawyer and politician, 26th President of Mexico (b. 1806)

entities.title: Benito Juárez
entities.description: Benito Pablo Juárez García was a Mexican lawyer and politician, who served as the 26th president of Mexico from 1858 until his death in 1872. He also served as the Mexican president during the Second French intervention in Mexico. He was the first president of Mexico who was of indigenous origin. Born in Oaxaca to a poor Zapotec rural family and orphaned when he was young, he moved to Oaxaca City

entities.title: President of Mexico
entities.description: The president of Mexico, officially known as the president of the United Mexican States, is the head of state and head of government of Mexico. Under the Constitution of Mexico, the President is the chief of the executive branch of the federal government and is the commander in chief of the Mexican Armed Forces. The current president is Andrés Manuel López Obrador, who took office on 1 December 20

heading: Deaths
txt: Ferdinand von Hochstetter, Austrian geologist and academic (b. 1829)

entities.title: Ferdinand von Hochstetter
entities.description: Christian Gottlieb Ferdinand Ritter von Hochstetter was a German-Austrian geologist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Dorothea Dix, American social reformer and activist (b. 1802)

entities.title: Dorothea Dix
entities.description: Dorothea Lynde Dix was an American advocate on behalf of the indigent mentally ill who, through a vigorous and sustained program of lobbying state legislatures and the United States Congress, created the first generation of American mental asylums. During the Civil War, she served as a Superintendent of Army Nurses.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lydia Becker, English journalist, author, and activist, co-founded the Women's Suffrage Journal (b. 1827)

entities.title: Lydia Becker
entities.description: Lydia Ernestine Becker was a leader in the early British suffrage movement, as well as an amateur scientist with interests in biology and astronomy. She is best remembered for founding and publishing the Women's Suffrage Journal between 1870 and 1890.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Cook, English travel agent, founded the Thomas Cook Group (b. 1808)

entities.title: Thomas Cook
entities.description: Thomas Cook was an English businessman. He is best known for founding the travel agency Thomas Cook & Son.

entities.title: Thomas Cook Group
entities.description: Thomas Cook Group plc was a British global travel group which was listed on the London Stock Exchange from its formation on 19 June 2007 by the merger of Thomas Cook AG and MyTravel Group until 23 September 2019 when it went into compulsory liquidation. The group operated as a tour operator and airline, in addition it also operated travel agencies in Europe.

heading: Deaths
txt: Horatio Alger, American novelist and journalist (b. 1832)

entities.title: Horatio Alger
entities.description: Horatio Alger Jr. was an American writer of young adult novels about impoverished boys and their rise from humble backgrounds to lives of middle-class security and comfort through good works. His writings were characterized by the "rags-to-riches" narrative, which had a formative effect on the United States during the Gilded Age.

heading: Deaths
txt: Benjamin C. Truman, American journalist and author (b. 1835)

entities.title: Benjamin C. Truman
entities.description: Benjamin Cummings Truman, was an American journalist and author; in particular, he was a distinguished war correspondent during the American Civil War, and an authority on duels.

heading: Deaths
txt: Louis-Nazaire Bégin, Canadian cardinal (b. 1840)

entities.title: Louis-Nazaire Bégin
entities.description: Louis-Nazaire Bégin was a Canadian Cardinal of the Catholic Church. Begin held a doctorate in Sacred Theology from the Pontifical Gregorian University in Rome and was later appointed Archbishop of Quebec by Pope Leo XIII (1898) and created cardinal by Pope Pius X (1914).

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean Jules Jusserand, French author and diplomat, French Ambassador to the United States (b. 1855)

entities.title: Jean Jules Jusserand
entities.description: Jean Adrien Antoine Jules Jusserand was a French author and diplomat. He was the French Ambassador to the United States during World War I.

entities.title: List of French ambassadors to the United States
entities.description: The French ambassador to the United States is the diplomatic representation of the French Republic to the United States. They reside in Washington, D.C.. The current ambassador is Philippe Étienne.

heading: Deaths
txt: Julian Bell, English poet and academic (b. 1908)

entities.title: Julian Bell
entities.description: Julian Heward Bell was an English poet, and the son of Clive and Vanessa Bell. The writer Quentin Bell was his younger brother and the writer and painter Angelica Garnett was his half-sister. His relationship with his mother is explored in Susan Sellers' novel Vanessa and Virginia.

heading: Deaths
txt: Marie of Romania (b. 1875)

entities.title: Marie of Romania
entities.description: Marie of Romania was the last Queen of Romania as the wife of King Ferdinand I.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Sturge Moore, English author, poet, and playwright (b. 1870)

entities.title: Thomas Sturge Moore
entities.description: Thomas Sturge Moore was a British poet, author and artist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Evald Tipner, Estonian footballer and ice hockey player (b. 1906)

entities.title: Evald Tipner
entities.description:
Evald Tipner was Estonian football, ice hockey and bandy player. He was capped 66 times for Estonian national football team, 7 times for bandy national team and once for ice hockey team. Tipner was also a good track and field athlete.
Some sources report him as the first goalscorer in the history of World Cup preliminary competition, having scored what would be an own goal for Sweden against Eston

heading: Deaths
txt: Herman Gummerus, Finnish historian, academic, and politician (b. 1877)

entities.title: Herman Gummerus
entities.description: Herman Gregorius Gummerus was a leading Finnish classical scholar, diplomat, and one of the founders of the Patriotic People's Movement (IKL).

heading: Deaths
txt: Vítězslav Novák, Czech composer and educator (b. 1870)

entities.title: Vítězslav Novák
entities.description: Vítězslav Augustín Rudolf Novák was a Czech composer and pedagogue. Stylistically, he was part of the neo-romantic tradition, and his music has been occasionally considered an early example of Czech modernism.

heading: Deaths
txt: Francisco Javier Arana, Guatemalan Army colonel and briefly Guatemalan head of state (b.1905)

heading: Deaths
txt: Carl Clinton Van Doren, American critic and biographer (b. 1885)

entities.title: Carl Clinton Van Doren
entities.description: Carl Clinton Van Doren was an American critic and biographer. He was the brother of critic and teacher Mark Van Doren and the uncle of Charles Van Doren.

heading: Deaths
txt: Paul Saintenoy, Belgian architect and historian (b. 1862)

entities.title: Paul Saintenoy
entities.description: Paul Saintenoy was a Belgian architect, teacher, architectural historian, and writer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Machine Gun Kelly, American gangster (b. 1895)

entities.title: Machine Gun Kelly
entities.description: George Kelly Barnes, better known by his pseudonym "Machine Gun Kelly", was an American gangster from Memphis, Tennessee, during the prohibition era. His nickname came from his favorite weapon, a Thompson submachine gun. He is best known for the kidnapping of the oil tycoon and businessman Charles F. Urschel in July 1933, from which he and his gang collected a $200,000 ransom. Urschel had collecte

heading: Deaths
txt: Bobby Fuller, American singer-songwriter and guitarist (b. 1942)

entities.title: Bobby Fuller
entities.description: Robert Gaston Fuller was an American rock singer, songwriter, and guitarist best known for "Let Her Dance" and his cover of "I Fought the Law" by the Crickets, recorded with his group The Bobby Fuller Four.

heading: Deaths
txt: Corneille Heymans, Belgian physiologist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1892)

entities.title: Corneille Heymans
entities.description: Corneille Jean François Heymans was a Belgian physiologist. He studied at the Jesuit College of Saint Barbara and then at Ghent University, where he obtained a doctor's degree in 1920.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine is awarded yearly by the Nobel Assembly at the Karolinska Institutet for outstanding discoveries in physiology or medicine.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mary Jo Kopechne, American educator and secretary (b. 1940)

entities.title: Mary Jo Kopechne
entities.description: Mary Jo Kopechne was an American secretary, one of the campaign workers for Robert F. Kennedy's 1968 presidential campaign, a close team known as the Boiler Room Girls. In 1969, she died in a car accident on Chappaquiddick Island, while being driven by U.S. Senator Ted Kennedy.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jack Hawkins, English actor (b. 1910)

entities.title: Jack Hawkins
entities.description: John Edward "Jack" Hawkins, CBE was an English actor who worked on stage and in film from the 1930s until the 1970s. One of the most popular British film stars of the 1950s, he was best known for his portrayal of military men.

heading: Deaths
txt: Vaughn Bodē, American illustrator (b. 1941)

entities.title: Vaughn Bodē
entities.description: Vaughn Bodē was an American underground cartoonist and illustrator known for his character Cheech Wizard and his artwork depicting voluptuous women. A contemporary of Ralph Bakshi, Bodē has been credited as an influence on Bakshi's animated films Wizards and The Lord of the Rings. Bodē has a huge following among graffiti artists, with his characters remaining a popular subject.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sonja Branting-Westerståhl, Swedish lawyer (b. 1890)

entities.title: Sonja Branting-Westerståhl
entities.description: Sonja Branting-Westerståhl was a Swedish lawyer and politician. She was one of the first female lawyers in Sweden and specialised in matrimonial law. A social democrat, she was active in raising awareness of the rise of far-right politics in 1930s and 1940s. In 1948, she served in the lower house of the Riksdag, the Swedish Parliament, for a short period.

heading: Deaths
txt: Roman Jakobson, Russian–American linguist and theorist (b. 1896)

entities.title: Roman Jakobson
entities.description: Roman Osipovich Jakobson was a Russian Empire-born American linguist and literary theorist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lally Bowers, English actress (b. 1914)

entities.title: Lally Bowers
entities.description: Kathleen "Lally" Bowers was an English actress.

heading: Deaths
txt: Grigori Kromanov, Estonian director and screenwriter (b. 1926)

heading: Deaths
txt: Gilberto Freyre, Brazilian sociologist, anthropologist, historian, writer, painter, journalist and congressman (b. 1907)

entities.title: Gilberto Freyre
entities.description: Gilberto de Mello Freyre was a Brazilian sociologist, anthropologist, historian, writer, painter, journalist and congressman, born in Recife, Pernambuco, Northeast Brazil. He is commonly associated with other major Brazilian cultural interpreters of the first half of the 20th century, such as Sérgio Buarque de Holanda and Caio Prado Júnior. His best-known work is a sociological treatise named Casa

heading: Deaths
txt: Nico, German singer-songwriter, keyboard player, and actress (b. 1938)

entities.title: Nico
entities.description: Christa Päffgen, known by her stage name Nico, was a German singer, songwriter, musician, model, and actress. She had roles in several films, including Federico Fellini's La Dolce Vita (1960) and Andy Warhol's Chelsea Girls (1966).

heading: Deaths
txt: Joly Braga Santos, Portuguese composer and conductor (b. 1924)

heading: Deaths
txt: Donnie Moore, American baseball player (b. 1954)

entities.title: Donnie Moore
entities.description: Donnie Ray Moore was an American relief pitcher in Major League Baseball (MLB) who played for the Chicago Cubs, St. Louis Cardinals (1980), Milwaukee Brewers (1981), Atlanta Braves (1982–84) and California Angels (1985–88). Moore is best remembered for the home run he gave up to Dave Henderson while pitching for the California Angels in Game 5 of the 1986 American League Championship Series. With

heading: Deaths
txt: Rebecca Schaeffer, American model and actress (b. 1967)

heading: Deaths
txt: Karl Menninger, American psychiatrist and author (b. 1896)

entities.title: Karl Menninger
entities.description: Karl Augustus Menninger was an American psychiatrist and a member of the Menninger family of psychiatrists who founded the Menninger Foundation and the Menninger Clinic in Topeka, Kansas.

heading: Deaths
txt: Yun Posun, South Korean politician, 2nd President of South Korea (b. 1897)

entities.title: President of South Korea
entities.description: The president of the Republic of Korea is the head of state and head of government of South Korea. The President is the head of the executive branch of the Government of South Korea as well as being the commander-in-chief of the Republic of Korea Armed Forces.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mimi Fariña, American singer-songwriter and guitarist (b. 1945)

entities.title: Mimi Fariña
entities.description: Margarita Mimi Baez Fariña was an American singer-songwriter and activist, the youngest of three daughters to a Scottish mother and Mexican-American physicist Albert Baez. She was the younger sister of the singer and activist Joan Baez.

heading: Deaths
txt: Metin Toker, Turkish journalist and author (b. 1924)

entities.title: Metin Toker
entities.description: Metin Toker was a Turkish journalist and writer.

heading: Deaths
txt: André Castelot, Belgian-French historian and author (b. 1911)

entities.title: André Castelot
entities.description: André Castelot, born André Storms, was a French writer and scriptwriter born in Belgium. He was the son of the Symbolist painter Maurice Chabas and Gabrielle Storms-Castelot, and the brother of the film actor Jacques Castelot. He wrote more than one hundred books, mostly biographies of famous people.

heading: Deaths
txt: Émile Peynaud, French wine maker (b. 1912)

heading: Deaths
txt: Amy Gillett, Australian cyclist and rower (b. 1976)

entities.title: Amy Gillett
entities.description: Amy Elizabeth Gillett was an Australian track cyclist and rower who represented Australia in both sports. She was killed when a driver crashed into the Australian squad of cyclists with whom she was training in Germany. The Amy Gillett Foundation was established in order to fund road safety programs and provide scholarships for young female cyclists.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Westmoreland, American general (b. 1914)

heading: Deaths
txt: Henry Hewes, American theater writer (b. 1917)

entities.title: Henry Hewes (critic)
entities.description: Henry Hewes was an American theater writer who worked as the drama critic for the Saturday Review weekly literary magazine from 1955 to 1979. He was the first major critic to regularly review regional and international theater. His interest in regional theater led him to found the American Theater Critics Association, the Tony Award for regional theater, and the American Theater Wing's design awar

heading: Deaths
txt: Jerry Hadley, American tenor (b. 1952)

entities.title: Jerry Hadley
entities.description: Jerry Hadley was an American operatic tenor. He received three Grammy awards for his vocal performances in the recordings of Jenůfa, Susannah, and Candide. Hadley was a leading American tenor for nearly two decades. He was mentored by soprano Joan Sutherland and her husband, conductor Richard Bonynge. Leonard Bernstein chose Hadley for his 1989 recording of Candide on Deutsche Grammophon. A versat

heading: Deaths
txt: Kenji Miyamoto, Japanese politician (b. 1908)

heading: Deaths
txt: Henry Allingham, English soldier (b. 1896)

entities.title: Henry Allingham
entities.description: Henry William Allingham was an English supercentenarian. He is the longest-lived man ever recorded from the United Kingdom, a First World War veteran, and, for one month, the verified oldest living man in the world. He is also the second-oldest military veteran ever, and, at the time of his death, he was the 12th-verified oldest man of all time.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jill Balcon, English actress (b. 1925)

heading: Deaths
txt: Yosef Shalom Eliashiv, Lithuanian-Israeli rabbi and author (b. 1910)

entities.title: Yosef Shalom Eliashiv
entities.description: Yosef Shalom Elyashiv was a Haredi Rabbi and posek who lived in Jerusalem. Until his death at the age of 102, Rav Elyashiv was the paramount leader of both Israel and the Diaspora Lithuanian-Haredi community, and many Ashkenazi Jews regarded him as the posek ha-dor, the contemporary leading authority on halakha, or Jewish law.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean François-Poncet, French politician and diplomat, French Minister of Foreign Affairs (b. 1928)

entities.title: Ministry of Foreign and European Affairs (France)
entities.description: The Ministry for Europe and Foreign Affairs is the ministry of the Government of France that handles France's foreign relations. Since 1855, its headquarters have been located at 37 Quai d'Orsay, close to the National Assembly. The term Quai d'Orsay is often used as a metonym for the ministry. Its cabinet minister, the Minister for Europe and Foreign Affairs is responsible for the foreign relation

heading: Deaths
txt: Vaali, Indian poet, songwriter, and actor (b. 1931)

entities.title: Vaali (poet)
entities.description: Vaali was an Indian poet and lyricist whose works were in Tamil, had a five-decade long association with the Tamil film industry, wrote over 15,000 songs. He acted in a number of films, including Sathya, Hey Ram, Paarthale Paravasam and Poikkal Kudhirai. He was honoured by the Government of India with the Padma Shri, India's fourth highest civilian honour.

txt: Olivier Ameisen,  French-American cardiologist and academic (b. 1953)

heading: Deaths
txt: Dietmar Schönherr, Austrian-Spanish actor, director, and screenwriter (b. 1926)

heading: Deaths
txt: Alex Rocco, American actor (b. 1936)

entities.title: Alex Rocco
entities.description: Alessandro Federico Petricone Jr., known professionally as Alex Rocco, was an American actor. Often cast as a villain, he is best known for his portrayal of Moe Greene in The Godfather and his Primetime Emmy Award-winning role in The Famous Teddy Z. He did a significant amount of voice-over work later in his career, and was known for his gravelly voice.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jonathan Gold, American food critic (b. 1960)

entities.title: Jonathan Gold
entities.description: Jonathan Gold was an American food critic and music critic. He was for many years the chief food critic for the Los Angeles Times and also wrote for LA Weekly and Gourmet, in addition to serving as a regular contributor on KCRW's Good Food radio program. Gold often chose small, traditional immigrant restaurants for his reviews, although he covered all types of cuisine. In 2007, while writing for t

heading: Deaths
